title: 109_hr799
content: The Act titled "Consumer Checking Account Fairness Act" requires adjustments to check hold periods. The Consumer Checking Account Fairness Act requires adjustments to check hold periods to coordinate with the Check Clearing for the 21st Century Act. The Board will prescribe regulations to reduce time periods for receiving institutions to learn of nonpayment of checks. The Consumer Checking Account Fairness Act requires adjustments to check hold periods to align with the Check Clearing for the 21st Century Act. The Board will eliminate distinctions between check schedules and extensions for deposits if they are found to be insignificant or not useful under the Act. The Board must finalize regulations required by the Consumer Checking Account Fairness Act within 6 months of its enactment. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO CHECKING ACCOUNT CONSUMERS. Amendments to the Expedited Funds Availability Act include allowing deposits at proprietary ATMs and limiting certain fees during the check hold period. The Expedited Funds Availability Act now prohibits depository institutions from charging fees for overdrafts if funds from a deposit are not yet available to the accountholder. Additionally, credits must be posted before debits in checking accounts used for personal purposes. The Expedited Funds Availability Act has been amended to treat Saturdays as business days for fund availability calculations. Additionally, the Act now requires funds from nonlocal check deposits to be available on the 2nd business day after deposit. The Expedited Funds Availability Act has been amended to increase the large check limitation to $7,500 and the small deposit availability to $500. The Availability Act is amended to change the coordination with other available amounts. Additionally, no fees can be imposed for paying checks without sufficient funds unless requested by the accountholder. Preemption clarification is also included in the amendments. The amendment clarifies that state laws providing greater consumer protection than federal laws are not considered inconsistent. The purpose of the federal law is to establish a minimum level of consumer protection, not to create a uniform national rule. The Checking for the 21st Century Act is amended to allow expedited recredit for all charges initiated by check, regardless of whether a substitute check was involved or provided to the consumer.
